info.title: NGINX One Spec
info.description: The API Reference documentation for NGINX One

tags.name: Data Plane Key
tags.description:
The `DataplaneKey` object represents a secure token required to establish a connection between your NGINX instances and NGINX One. 
As a fundamental security measure, the data plane key ensures that only trusted NGINX instances can register and communicate with NGINX One. 

Data plane keys automatically expire after one year. However, you can extend this expiration date if needed.

Revoking a data plane key will disconnect the associated NGINX instances from NGINX One.

**IMPORTANT** Data plane keys are not saved and are displayed only once when you generate them. You should save this key in a secure location for future reference.

tags.name: Instances
tags.description:
The `Instance` object represents an active NGINX deployment. 
You can access detailed information about each NGINX instance, including its configuration analysis, security advisories, and operational status.

get.description:
Returns system metrics for NGINX instances based on query parameters.

You can filter metrics by name and timestamp, aggregate metrics over a configurable period of time, and group metrics by dimension.

parameters.name: names
parameters.description:
Specify the metrics you want information on.

Usage: 
* List the names of metrics you want, separated by commas.
* When using aggregate functions like `avg()`, `sum()`, `count()`, `min()`, `max()`, or `rate()` on metrics, you must also set a `start_time`.
* If your query includes both aggregated and non-aggregated metrics, the `group_by` setting will apply only to the aggregated metrics.
* Aggregated metrics require a `start_time`.

parameters.name: group_by
parameters.description:
Group your query results by the specified dimension(s).

Usage:
* Provide multiple dimensions as a comma-separated list.
* All metrics in the `names` parameter must be aggregated.

parameters.name: series_limit
parameters.description:
Limits the number of series returned in the response. 

Usage:
* Use this parameter in conjunction with `order_series_by` for sorting.
* You muse use exactly one `group_by` parameter in your query.
* This parameter is incompatible with the `dimensions` parameter.

Notes:
* Always returns an additional series called `all`, which aggregates values from all the metrics in the results.
* If `all` doesn't encompass every stored dimension, a series named `other` will be included, providing aggregated values for metrics not included in `all`.

parameters.name: order_series_by
parameters.description:
Sets the sort order of the metric series in your results. The default is descending order by total sum (`SUM DESC`) if no sort order is specified.

Usage:

* Use with `series_limit` to apply the sort order to a specific number of series.

parameters.name: dimensions
parameters.description:
Specify which dimensions to use for categorizing metric data.

Note: To return a single series without categorization, provide the metric name and aggregation function, and leave the `dimensions` parameter blank.

Usage:

* List the dimensions you want to include as a comma-separated list.
* If you do not include a dimension, it will not appear in the results.
* When you use the `aggregation and `group_by` parameters, any dimension specified here for `dimensions` must be also specified in `group_by`.
* You do not need to list dimensions in `dimensions` if you are already including them in `group_by`, unless you want to display them in the results.
* To return a single series without categorization, provide the metric name and aggregation function, and leave this `dimensions` parameter blank.
* This parameter is incompatible with the `series_limit` parameter.
* `Tenant` and `Namespace` are not valid dimensions for this parameter; include these as headers instead.

parameters.name: start_time
parameters.description:
Use `start_time` to set the start of the time period for your metrics query. It marks the earliest time from which metrics are included.

Important points:
* You must use `start_time` if you're also specifying `end_time`.
* If you don't set `start_time`, the API automatically gives you the most recent metrics.
* For aggregated metrics (like averages or sums over time), `start_time` is required to calculate the resolution.

parameters.name: end_time
parameters.description:
`end_time` sets the end of the time period for your metrics query (non-inclusive).

Keep in mind:
* `end_time` must be a time after `start_time`.
* If you set `start_time` but not `end_time`, the system assumes `end_time` is now (the current time).

parameters.name: filter
parameters.description:
`filter` helps you pick only the results you need by using key value pairs, formatted as `<key><operator><value>`.

Create a filter with:
* `<key>`: This is the dimension you want to filter on (like `count`).
* `<operator>`: Choose from `=`, `!=`, `<`, `<=`, `>`, `>=`, `in`, `not`.
* `<value>`: The specific value you're looking for in the dimension.
* Both `<key> and <value>` are case sensitive.

Example: `count > 100`

Combine multiple filters using `AND`, `OR`, and parentheses `( )`. Use a wildcard `*` for partial matches. 
Always put filters in single quotes for proper processing.

See the Dimensions Catalog to learn more about dimensions.

Note: You can't filter by `Tenant` or `Namespace`. These can be provided only as headers.

schema.example: ((server_zone!='server_zone_1' OR server_zone='server_zone_2') AND nginx_id in ('id1', 'id2')) AND (system.tags!='*tag1*')

parameters.name: resolution
parameters.description:
`resolution` sets how detailed time series data you get will be. It's only for endpoints that return time series data.

It must be a valid duration. Format as a string starting with a number followed by a unit of time, such as `y` (years), `M` (months), `w` (weeks), `d` (days), `h` (hours), `m` (minutes) or `s` (seconds).

When using the Metrics API:
  * Combine `resolution` with an aggregate function (or functions) in the `names` parameter, and set a `start_time`.
  * If you don't specify `resolution,` the API uses the broadest resolution based on the time between `start_time` and `end_time.`

get.description:
Returns a list of all the metrics available in the NGINX One Metrics Catalog. 
This catalog provides detailed definitions of each metric, helping you to better understand the available metrics and refine your analytics queries.

Retrieves detailed information about a specific metric in the NGINX One Metrics Catalog.
This detailed view helps you see how a metric can be used for monitoring and analytics.

The response includes:
* Name and description of the metric, explaining what it measures.
* Applicable types of aggregations (for example `AVG`, `SUM`).
* Categories to which the metric belongs, like 'nginx'.
* Associated dimensions, showing different ways to analyze the metric.
* Type and unit of the metric, such as 'incremental' and 'bytes'.

Paginated.name: paginated
Paginated.description:
A boolean indicating if the results should be presented as a paginated list. Defaults to `true`. 
When set to `false`, the results are returned as a condensed, non-paginated list.

Limit.name: limit
Limit.description:
An integer that specifies the maximum number of items to be returned. 
Setting this to `0` will result in no items being returned, but a total count will still be provided. 
This parameter is not applicable if `paginated` is `false`.

Offset.name: offset
Offset.description:
An integer that specifies the starting position of the results, starting at `1`. Any values less than `1` are treated as `1`. 
This is parameter is not not applicable if `paginated` is `false`.

FilterFieldDataplaneKeys.name: filter_fields
FilterFieldDataplaneKeys.description:
Filter options for data plane keys; used in conjunction with other filter parameters having the same array length.

When filtering on `status`, only the following `filter_values` are supported:
  * revoked
  * valid

FilterOperands.name: filter_ops
FilterOperands.description:
An array of strings defining the operands for filtering, to be used in conjunction with `filter_fields` and `filter_values`. 
All filter parameters must have matching array lengths. Currently, the only supported operand is `"IN"`.

FilterValues.name: filter_values
FilterValues.description:
An array of strings containing the keywords for filtering. 
Each keyword should be alphanumeric and multiple keywords can be chained using the `|` character. 
Ensure this parameter's array length matches those of `filter_fields` and `filter_ops` for effective filtering.
The total length of the filter string should not exceed 1024 characters.

DataplaneKeyUUID.name: dataplaneKeyUUID
DataplaneKeyUUID.description: The unique identifier (UUID) for the data plane key.

FilterFieldInstances.name: filter_fields
FilterFieldInstances.description: An array of strings indicating which fields to filter by (for example, `hostname`, `nginx_version`). This parameter works in conjunction with `filter_values` and `filter_ops`.

InstanceUUID.name: instanceUUID
InstanceUUID.description: The unique identifier (UUID) for the NGINX instance.

FilterNameDataplaneKeys.description:
Keywords for data plane key filters.
When filtering on `status`, only the following `filter_values` are supported:
  * revoked
  * valid

Status of the certificate:
  * `valid` - The certificate is currently valid and operational.
  * `expiring` -  The certificate will expire within the next 30 days. Consider renewing it to maintain uninterrupted service.
  * `expired` - The certificate is no longer valid. Immediate renewal is recommended to ensure secure connections.

The NGINX Agent is connected to NGINX One, and the NGINX instance is online.

offline.description:

The NGINX Agent is connected to NGINX One, but the NGINX instance is offline.

The NGINX Agent has lost connection to NGINX One, rendering the NGINX instance unavailable.

status.description:
The current operational status of the NGINX instance, with the following possible values:
* `unknown` - The status of the NGINX instance cannot be determined at this moment.
* `unavailable` - The NGINX Agent has lost connection to NGINX One, rendering the NGINX instance unavailable.
* `offline` - The NGINX Agent is connected to NGINX One, but the NGINX instance is offline.
* `online` - The NGINX Agent is connected to NGINX One, and the NGINX instance is online.

Time.description:
Indicates a point in time.

Time can be specified in two ways:
* ISO 8601 format, which looks like "2019-08-07T09:57:36.088757764Z".
* As an offset from the current time, using a string that starts with `+` or `-`, followed by a number and a time unit. Units include `y` (years), `M` (months), `w` (weeks), `d` (days), `h` (hours), `m` (minutes), or `s` (seconds). 
Example of an offset: "now-3h" (3 hours before now).
